children.subject: From what I've heard, the policy under debate specifically affects undeclared L&S students who applied for a major other than CS. Students who have already declared CS won't be removed from the major, though the budget issues that have caused long waitlists and tight enrollment from past semester still persist.
EDIT: misread post. see below.

What would be the million dollar answer? I have a similar question. I’m declared CS and was admitted as CS-intended, has the proposal to limit the maximum number of upper division CS classes one could take been rejected or is it still on the table?
The million dollar answer is that it will affect current students unless the department can get another million dollars.

Indeed, the million dollar answer is a million dollars to support current non-declared Berkeley students.

There is no proposal to limit the maximum number of CS upper divs, nor is there a proposal to make any changes for students who are already CS declared.

And the $6 million alternative is that the University refunds approximately 400 students for the one-year of coursework they wasted trying to pursue a major they were promised they could persue. (~400 students x $15k tuition)
<md>Does the policy affect students who entered prior to Fall 2022? At the time of applying there was no such policy in place so it doesn't make sense to put current students in this</md>

Oops I somehow misread the original question. There is no possible enrollment policy change for declared majors. There may be a chance for students who are not yet declared. I agree that it makes no sense to change enrollment policies for students who are here but we cannot hire teaching assistants without money. If it starts turning that way then I'll be working 100% time to avoid enrollment changes for students who are already here.
<md>I have completed CS 61a and am taking CS 70 and 61b this semester. Do I need to worry about my likelihood to declare l&s cs?</md>
Comp: No
Will it also affect COE other majors trying to switch to EECS?

There have been no decisions made. As noted above, I'll be devoting all my effort to keeping classes open to students who are already here (COE, other L&S majors, etc) if it starts looking like they will close.
Regarding the enrollment policy change, does it also affect students who are already CS-major declared?

CS-intended students will experience no change.

The decision isn't being made by EECS and we are entirely at the mercy of the funding situation. If we have money, we will open our classes to students already at Berkeley. If we have even more money, we will open our classes for students arriving Fall 2022.

I know people have already talked about the possible impact of the enrollment policy change on declared CS students, but I am wondering what the possible impact on CS-intended students (people who picked intended major CS on the UC app) who are not yet declared will be.

Also, is there a timeline for when the EECS department will finalize their decision?

Sorry for the delay y'all - I created the document this morning & am asking for help posting it to a location where EVERYONE can access it. When I have that link, I'll edit my original post to include it. I am hopeful I can do that later today.
no worries! thanks for the update and all your work with regards classes and scheduling!

I just edited the original post to include a link to the in-process schedule. There will be no enrollment information listed there. Here's the link again on this post for quick reference. (remember, it's subject to multiple changes!)
Will the document be posted?
As the original post indicated - the EECS/ELENG classes are on the schedule already with as much info as is known.
Are the ELENG/EECS classes visible on the class schedule confirmed? (Since they're not on the link.) In particular, is EECS 16B's offering confirmed, and if so, will we know who the teacher will be?
The intention is for CS 188 to be taught. The instructor is still being finalized.
As with the other responses, the intention is to offer both of these classes but teaching assignments are not confirmed for them so I am not listing the classes right now.
161 is also waiting for confirmation on instructor, but will likely be offered.
Are 161/188 not being offered next sem? :(

F

sahai is the only one who can save us
The intention is to teach it but again, instructor schedule/potential sabbatical are still not settled so it's not confirmed. I'm only including CONFIRMED classes on this list.
Is CS285 planning to be offered next semester?
Intended but not confirmed yet. My list is only showing CONFIRMED offerings.
Is 261 planning on being offered?
It is at risk of not being offered - depending upon teaching staff schedule/potential sabbatical.

Oh noooOOoo! Ah, that's unfortunate to hear, but understandable. Sabbaticals, rest, and/or doing something new are important.

This is still sad news for me though because I've been looking forward to this class for like forever. I remember meeting one of the professors during a summer program my first year at Cal and him giving a super cool and fascinating presentation on the fields (Computer Vision, etc.) related to this class, his research, and more. I remember him being really enthusiastic about us new students expanding our CS skills at Berkeley and encouraging us to study these topics if we found them interesting. It was quite motivating to hear him say something along the lines of "You all can succeed, and it'd be great to have you join my research or some other CS field and share the ideas from your bright minds" (very rough recall; it's been a while, haha). I remember laughing at his jokes and having a blast in that fleeting snapshot of a meaningful moment. The whole presentation was inspiring. So, I sincerely hope they have a good sabbatical if they do that (and wish them well in general), but aw, I was really, really, really, reallylooking forward to taking this class this Fall semester.

What should I instead? Thoughts? Thanks :)
Omg, this class has now been confirmed on the class doc. Fantastic!
Is CS 194-26 not listed because it is a 194 or is it actually at risk of being offered? 🥺
As happens with cross-listed classes sometimes...I have no info on that class right now.

That being said, it is true 106A is also only offered in the fall.
164 is slated to be offered in SP23 per the draft schedule, fwiw.

@Anon Gear3 the spring version of 164 is with a different professor and 164 varies a lot by professor. If you want the fall version then I guess I’ll have to choose between 164 and 168 unless one gets moved.

I can't speak for either class, but my understanding is that once a room booking and lecture time is confirmed with the university, it's quite difficult to change it, so I doubt either class is changing their lecture time at this point. You might be able to enroll in both if one of them allows time conflicts, maybe?
@Anon Beaker2, 106A doesnt have a final so you can definitely override it and both classes are webcasted.

It's true - trying to manage faculty scheduling constraints along with campus schedule rules AND very limited campus classroom space is nightmarish. (Did you know, each semester 1500 classes across campus vie for 200 rooms?)  While I do my best to avoid time conflicts, it literally is impossible to do so.

Wow, that's crazy.
Thanks for putting in the effort for us.

Hopefully they are time conflicts allowed.

Happily, there is movement happening behind the scenes regarding CompSci enrollments and while we are not ready to share data yet, I anticipate we will be able have our classes open when phase 1 opens.

Too many pieces in flux for me to know anything on this topic at this time. (Ugh, I sound like a magic 8 ball - sorry) Best I can say is that it's well after hours for staff to be working & here I am, doing my best to get things settled for y'all.
I'm graduating this semester, but I just wanted to say thank you to Cindy for working so hard on this and being an advocate for all of us!
Thanks everyone! I'm happy to support such an amazing group of humans as best I can through some really crazy times.

Seriously. Thank you Cindy and to all the other staff members diligently working so hard to figure these logistics out. I'm getting second-hand stress just thinking about the billion logistical tasks behind the scenes for organizing all of this.
Will the waitlist be re-shuffled with EECS/CS majors put on the top for CS upper divs this semester?

Not until phase 1 begins & they won't be accurate until later next week. Let's just say that I have to re-do much of that work once final decisions are made & I can't get that work done AND be ready to open classes on time.

But remember, CompSci uses 999 (placeholder) discussion & lab sections so you will be able to enroll & then check back at the end of next week to learn about the labs and discussion sections. (And if you haven't done this dance before, the teaching staff are the ones who assign the lab/discussion sections outside the enrollment system just prior to/during the first week of classes.)
+1 typically discussions/lab are "go to what you want" and are released with tons of flexibility in the first few weeks of class. I really enjoy this system
Well, keep in mind that it's up to each faculty member to decide how they want to manage the section assignments so what you have experienced in some classes may not be true for all classes. :-)

This would be a good question for the professor.

It’s a suggestion, not a hard requirement.
how strict is cs168 with the cs162 prereq requirement?
Probably depends on the instructor, and we don't know who the instructor is yet, so not sure anyone knows.

Given that we don't know the instructor, I'm going to open the class as NOT allowing time conflicts and we can revisit that once an instructor has been assigned.

This is the more conservative enrollment approach - I'd hate to have people waste phase 1 units enrolling with a time conflict only to find out they won't be allowed & then have to drop.

If you want to enroll with a time conflict, you will still be able to join a waitlist with phase 1 units to give yourself the best chance of getting in later is the policy is relaxed.

While leadership continues to work things out, I'm starting to input the info into the system behind the scenes so that when that approval comes, I can mark a bunch of checkboxes to reveal the classes to you.

My best suggestion is to check back around 2pm. I'll post an update to my original post then to let you know what I know then.

I am waiting to hear back from Prof Ratnasamy before I can ask to expand enrollment past the room capacity for this class. Once that happens, I will be able to add another 143 seats for EECS/LSCS majors.  Until then please remain on the waitlist.

I am a declared LS CS student (declared a couple semester ago and it is on my cal central) but I just got waitlisted for CS168 when there are still seats reserved for CS majors? I was wondering why that might be? Thank you!

I am L&S undeclared student, and plan to take CS 70 in the fall.  But cal central doesn't allow me to enroll in CS 70.  I am wondering what I need to show that I meet the reserve capacity requirement.
Since this thread is about CompSci classes only, you will need to email eecs-advising@eecs.berkeley.edu with that question.

What are the chances that I get off the 106a waitlist, currently in position 27? This is the third year been waitlisted for this course and my last chance to take the class, since I am graduating next year :(

history.content:
4/15/22 5:30pm UPDATE: I've now posted information but started another thread. Please read @16779.

4/15/22 2pm UPDATE: Unfortunately I am still working with campus behind the scenes for approvals. Please check back at 4:30pm.

4/13/2022 UPDATE:

In the spirit of transparency, I can say that movement is happening regarding CompSci enrollments - yay! Please continue to be patient as we work behind the scenes to make sure everyone is in agreement with final decisions, I set the classes up in the system for you to see, & we work on some clear messaging. 

I cannot say when you will hear more information, but at this point I expect to be able to open CompSci classes for enrollment when phase 1 begins. That said, expect there still to be some unknowns regarding specific class offerings but we will open as many classes as we can when phase 1 opens.

Cindy

4/11/2022 UPDATE:

Unfortunately I do not have an update for you today beyond letting you know that we are waiting on guidance from EVCP regarding budget and enrollment policies. Unfortunately we do not have a date when any decisions will be made or any more information will become available. I have been told that EVCP is aware that phase 1 opens on 4/18.

We know this lack of information impacts your ability to plan and we regret the stress and uncertainty. EECS leadership, faculty, and staff are doing all that we can to mitigate the impact to students and resolve this situation as quickly as possible.

Reminder: You can see the intended Fall 2022 class schedule here. I will continue to update the list as more teaching assignments are confirmed. So, again, if you do not see a class listed, it may simply be that it's not confirmed yet. I CAN say that we do not intend to offer CS 160 or CS 169A during Fall 2022.

I expect (but cannot confirm) that messaging will be sent to students directly once decisions are made. I will do another update here as well so keep checking back throughout the week for updates.

Cindy Conners

CompSci Enrollment Manager

4/1/2022 UPDATE:

As discussions continue, we are still unable to make the Computer Science schedule visible by 4/2/22 as we had hoped. You can expect the next update on 4/11/2022 when return from being out of the office. Sorry for the delay everyone. I know it's challenging to live with uncertainty for so long. 

Cindy Conners

CompSci Enrollment Manager

============================

Unfortunately, EECS will not be able to release the Fall 2022 Computer Science schedule on March 27th when other class schedules are available to students. (ELENG & EECS classes WILL be visible starting March 27th.)

There are multiple reasons for this delay:

  • Enrollment policies are not finalized for the Fall 2022 semester

  • Not all CompSci classes have been assigned rooms yet which means the schedule is subject to change

  • In a few cases, we are still working to confirm teaching assignments to know if we can offer certain CS classes.

 

We understand and regret that this delay impacts students’ ability to plan their schedules for Fall 2022. Our intention is to resolve the issues named above and make the schedule visible by April 2nd. 

 

To mitigate the impact on student’s ability to make plans, I will make public an ‘in-progress’ list of confirmed class days/times on Monday, March 28th and will update that list as we work to resolve the outstanding issues pertaining to room and teaching assignments. Here's a link to the in-process CompSci schedule to use for schedule planning purposes. (Remember, it's subject to multiple changes over time.) THESE ARE CLASSES WE DEFINITELY KNOW WILL BE TAUGHT. We intend to teach others but until they are CONFIRMED, I am not listing them. (CS 188, CS 161, CS 261, etc.)

 

Regarding enrollment policy changes - EECS leadership, faculty and staff are fully aware that students want more information. Unfortunately, I am unable to provide any insight regarding that matter. EECS leadership will communicate with students regarding Fall 2022 CompSci enrollments as soon as information is finalized.

Cindy Conners

CS Scheduler & Enrollment Manager
